Manchin III''' (born August 24, 1947) is an American politician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] [[United States Senator]] from [[West Virginia]], a seat he has held since 2010. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he previously served as the 34th [[Governor of West Virginia]] from 2005 to 2010 and the 27th [[Secretary of State of West Virginia]] from 2001 to 2005.
Manchin has been known throughout his career to be a conservative Democrat, a fact which has allowed him to hold office in West Virginia even as the state shifted from one of the most heavily Democratic in the country to one of the most heavily Republican.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/10/24/451336317/west-virginia-tells-the-story-of-americas-shifting-political-climate|title=West Virginia Tells The Story Of America's Shifting Political Climate|publisher=}}</ref> He won by a large margin the [[West Virginia gubernatorial election, 2004|2004 West Virginia gubernatorial election]] and reelected with an even larger margin in [[West Virginia gubernatorial election, 2008|2008]], even though in both years Republican presidential candidates captured the majority of West Virginia's votes. He won the [[United States Senate special election in West Virginia, 2010|special election in November 2010]] to fill the seat of Senator [[Robert Byrd]], the longest serving U.S. Senator in history, who died in office. Manchin was [[United States Senate election in West Virginia, 2012|elected to a full term]] in office with 60 percent of the vote in November 2012. Manchin became the state's senior U.S. Senator when [[Jay Rockefeller]] retired in 2015.
As a member of Congress, Manchin is known for his [[bipartisanship]], voting or working with [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] on issues such as abortion and gun ownership. He opposed the energy policies of President [[Barack Obama]], declined to vote on both the [[Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010]] and the [[DREAM ACT]], voted for removing federal funding from [[Planned Parenthood]] in 2015 (but voted to preserve funding for the organization in 2017), and voted to confirm most of President [[Donald Trump]]'s cabinet appointees. In 2017, he voted against allowing states to divert money away from abortion providers. Manchin has repeatedly voted against attempts to repeal the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], also known as Obamacare. He voted against the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|2017 Republican tax plan]]. Manchin has complained about the "toxic" lack of bipartisanship in Congress on almost every issue. "Liberal activists argue he is too conservative for the Democratic Party, while Republicans argue he is too liberal for West Virginia."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Foran|first1=Clare|title=West Virginia's Conservative Democrat Gets a Primary Challenger|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/joe-manchin-bernie-sanders-primary-challenge-west-virginia-senate-2018/525918/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=March 22, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Manchin was born in 1947 in [[Farmington, West Virginia]], a small coal mining town, the second of five children of Mary O. (n√©e Gouzd) and John Manchin.<ref name=USNews>{{cite web |title=10 Things You Didn't Know About West Virginia Gov. Joe Manchin |url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/campaign-2008/2008/08/01/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-west-virginia-gov-joe-manchin.html |date=August 1, 2008 |accessdate=May 11, 2009|author=Burton, Danielle |publisher=[[US News & World Report]]}}</ref><ref name=dla>{{Cite news|last=|first=|title=Manchin's mom was a tomboy in her youth|pages=|publisher=Beckley Register-Herald|date=December 26, 2009|url=http://www.register-herald.com/statenews/x546334413/Manchin-s-mom-was-a-tomboy-in-her-youth|accessdate=November 3, 2010}}</ref> Manchin was derived from "Mancini". His father was of [[Italy|Italian]] descent and his maternal grandparents were [[Czechoslovak]] [[immigration|immigrants]].<ref name=USNews/><ref name=vt-z>{{Cite news|last=Baxter|first=Anna|title=Day 2: Democratic National Convention|pages=|publisher=WSAZ-TV|date=August 26, 2008|url=http://www.wsaz.com/political/headlines/27439319.html|accessdate=November 3, 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
His father owned a carpet and furniture store, and his grandfather, Joseph Manchin, owned a grocery store.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wvobserver.com/2010/07/a-day-with-joe-manchin/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807232205/http://www.wvobserver.com/2010/07/a-day-with-joe-manchin/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 7, 2010|title=The Observer ¬ª Blog Archive ¬ª A Day with Joe Manchin|date=August 7, 2010|publisher=}}</ref> His father and his grandfather both served as Mayor of [[Farmington, West Virginia]]. His uncle, [[A. James Manchin|A.J. Manchin]], was a member of the [[West Virginia House of Delegates]] and was elected as the state's [[West Virginia Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] and [[Treasurer]].<ref>[http://nationaljournal.com/pubs/almanac/2006/people/wv/wvgv.htm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105013606/http://nationaljournal.com/pubs/almanac/2006/people/wv/wvgv.htm|date=January 5, 2012}}</ref>
Manchin graduated from [[North Marion High School (West Virginia)|Farmington High School]] in 1965.<ref name=OurStates>{{cite news |title=Joe Manchin III |author=Fournier, Eddie |work=Our States: West Virginia [serial online] |date=November 2008 |pages=1‚Äì3 |publisher=[[EBSCO Publishing]] |isbn=1-4298-1207-9}}</ref> He entered [[West Virginia University]] on a [[American football|football]] [[athletic scholarship|scholarship]] in 1965; however, an injury during practice ended his football career. He graduated in 1970 with a degree in [[Bachelor of Business Administration#Information management|business administration]] and later became involved in several family-owned businesses.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
==Early political career== Manchin was elected to the [[West Virginia House of Delegates]] in 1982 at the age of 35 and was elected to the [[West Virginia Senate]] in 1986, where he served until 1996. He ran for Governor in 1996, finishing second to [[Charlotte Pritt]] among a large group of candidates in the Democratic [[primary election]]. He later ran and was elected as [[Secretary of State of West Virginia]] in 2000.
==Governor of West Virginia== Manchin announced his intention to challenge incumbent [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Governor, [[Bob Wise]], in the 2004 Democratic [[primary election]] in May 2003. Wise decided not to seek re-election after a scandal, and Manchin won the Democratic primary and [[West Virginia gubernatorial election, 2004|general election]] by large margins. His election marked the first time that two people of the same political party had followed one another in the West Virginia Governor's office since 1964.
[[File:Joe Manchin (2894754698) (cropped1).png|thumb|left|Manchin speaks during the second day of the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]] in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], [[Colorado]], in his capacity as chair of the [[Democratic Governors Association]].]] Manchin was a member of the [[National Governors Association]], the [[Southern Governors' Association]], and the [[Democratic Governors Association]]. He was also chairman of the Southern States Energy Board, state's chair of the [[Appalachian Regional Commission]] and chairman of the Interstate Mining Compact Commission.
In July 2005, [[Massey Energy]] [[chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Don Blankenship]] sued Manchin, alleging that Manchin had violated Blankenship's [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights by threatening increased government scrutiny of his coal operations in retaliation for Blankenship's political activities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Massey CEO sues W.Va. governor in federal court|url=http://www.ohvec.org/links/news/archive/2005/fair_use/07_27.html|publisher=The Herald-Dispatch|accessdate=May 26, 2012|author=JENNIFER BUNDY|date=July 27, 2005}}</ref> Blankenship had donated substantial funds into campaigns to defeat a proposed pension bond amendment and oppose the re-election of [[Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia|state Supreme Court]] Justice [[Warren McGraw]],<ref>{{cite web|title=West Virginia: The story behind the score|url=http://www.stateintegrity.org/westvirginia_story_subpage|publisher=stateintegrity.org|accessdate=May 26, 2012|author=Eric Newhouse|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120522133040/http://www.stateintegrity.org/westvirginia_story_subpage|archivedate=May 22, 2012|df=}}</ref> and he fought against a proposed increase in the [[severance tax]] on extraction of mineral resources.<ref>{{cite web|title=The WV Coal Equation: Living With Past Peak Production|url=http://calhounpowerline.com/2010/04/17/wv-coal-living-with-past-peak-production/|publisher=calhounpowerline.com|accessdate=May 26, 2012|date=April 17, 2010}}</ref> Soon after defeat of the pension bond amendment, the state Division of Environmental Protection (DEP) revoked a permit approval for controversial new [[silo]]s near Marsh Fork Elementary School in [[Raleigh County, West Virginia|Raleigh County]]. While area residents had complained for some time that the coal operation there endangered their children, Blankenship claimed that the DEP acted in response to his opposition to the bond amendment.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rape of Appalachia|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/2006/05/appalachia200605|publisher=Vanity Fair|accessdate=May 26, 2012|author=Michael Shnayerson|date=May 2005}}</ref>
During the [[2006 Sago Mine disaster]] in early January 2006 in [[Upshur County, West Virginia]], Manchin appeared to confirm incorrect reports that 12 miners had survived;{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} in actuality only one survived. Manchin later acknowledged that an unintentional miscommunication had occurred with rescue teams in the mine.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} On February 1, 2006, he ordered a stop to all coal production in West Virginia, pending safety checks, after two more miners were killed in separate accidents.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KgIyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OaoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1129,4463371&dq=governor+asks+coal+mines+to+stop+production&hl=en|title=W.Va. governor asks for halt in coal production|author=Lawrence Messina|agency=Associated Press|work=The Beauford Gazette|date=February 2, 2006|accessdate=December 30, 2010}}</ref> Sixteen West Virginia coal miners died from mining accidents in early 2006. In November 2006, [[SurveyUSA]] ranked him as one of the most popular governors in the country with a 74 percent approval rating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Approval Ratings For All 50 Governors|date=November 20, 2006|publisher=SurveyUSA|url=http://www.surveyusa.com/50State2006/State50StateGovernor061120.htm }}</ref>
Manchin easily won re-election to a second term as governor in [[West Virginia gubernatorial election, 2008|2008]] against Republican [[Russ Weeks]], capturing 69.77% percent of the vote and winning every county.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gov. Manchin wins second term|url=http://www.wvpubcast.org/newsarticle.aspx?id=5924|publisher=West Virginia Public Broadcasting|accessdate=April 26, 2012|author=Jessica Lilly|date=November 5, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130416052925/http://www.wvpubcast.org/newsarticle.aspx?id=5924|archivedate=April 16, 2013|df=}}</ref>
==U.S. Senate==
===Elections===
====2010==== {{Main|United States Senate special election in West Virginia, 2010}} [[File:Senator Byrd funeral service.jpg|thumb|Memorial service for [[Robert Byrd]] at the State Capitol in [[Charleston, West Virginia]], July 2, 2010]] [[File:Joe Manchin, Official Senate Portrait.jpg|thumb|Manchin's 112th Congressional session portrait]] Due to the declining health of Senator [[Robert Byrd]], speculation focused on what Manchin's response would be if Byrd died. The governor consistently refused to comment on the subject prior to Byrd's death, except for stating that he would not appoint himself to the position.<ref>{{YouTube|3Hw56gkJIPE|Joe Manchin stated that he would not select himself for the US senate position should Robert Byrd be unable to serve a full term}}{{dead link|date=December 2010}}</ref> Byrd died on June 28, 2010,<ref>{{cite web |author=Lisa Lerer |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-06-28/robert-byrd-longest-serving-u-s-senator-dies-at-92.html |title=Robert Byrd, Longest-Serving U.S. Senator, Dies at 92 |publisher=Bloomberg Business Week |date=June 28, 2010 |accessdate=December 29, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100702010614/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-06-28/robert-byrd-longest-serving-u-s-senator-dies-at-92.html |archivedate=July 2, 2010 |df= }}</ref> and Manchin appointed [[Carte Goodwin]], his 36-year-old legal adviser, on July 16.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/POLITICS/07/16/pol.byrd.vacant.seat/index.html?eref=rss_politics&iref=polticker |work=CNN |title=West Virginia governor to name Byrd replacement|author=CNN Wire Staff | date= July 16, 2010|accessdate=December 30, 2010}}</ref>
On July 20, 2010, Manchin announced he would seek the Senate seat.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/thefix/senate/west-virginia-gov-joe-manchin.html |work=The Washington Post |title=W.Va. Gov. Joe Manchin launches Senate campaign; Capitol on deck|date=July 20, 2010|accessdate=December 30, 2010|author=Aaron Blake}}</ref> In the Democratic [[Primary election|primary]] on August 28, he defeated former Democratic Congressman and former West Virginia Secretary of State [[Ken Hechler]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wsaz.com/senateelection/headlines/101729108.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130206132721/http://www.wsaz.com/senateelection/headlines/101729108.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 6, 2013 |title=Manchin & Raese Nominees for Byrd's Senate Seat |author=Associated Press staff reporter |agency=Associated Press |publisher=WSAZ.com |accessdate=December 29, 2010 }}</ref> In the general election, he then defeated Republican [[John Raese]].
====2012==== {{main|United States Senate election in West Virginia, 2012}} Manchin chose to stand for reelection to a full term in 2012. According to the Democratic firm [[Public Policy Polling]], early polling found Manchin heavily favored, leading Congresswoman [[Shelley Moore Capito]] 50‚Äì39, 2010 opponent [[John Raese]] 60‚Äì31, and Congressman [[David McKinley]] 57‚Äì28.<ref name="PPP">{{cite news |title=Manchin leads Capito, Raese, McKinley for 2012 re-election|url= http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/PPP_Release_WV_0125424.pdf |publisher=[[Public Policy Polling]] |date=January 25, 2011}}</ref> Manchin had not endorsed his party's candidate, President Barack Obama, for the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], saying that he had "some real differences" with the presumptive nominees of both major parties, finding fault with Obama's [[Economic policy of Barack Obama|economic]] and [[energy policy of the Obama administration|energy policies]], and questioning [[Political positions of Mitt Romney|Romney's understanding]] of the "challenges facing ordinary people."<ref>{{cite web|title=Dem Senator Doesn't Know If He Will Vote For Obama |date=April 20, 2012 |url= http://washington.cbslocal.com/2012/04/20/dem-senator-doesnt-know-if-he-will-vote-for-obama/ |publisher= [[CBS Radio|CBS Local Media]]| work=[[WDCH-FM|WNEW-FM]]}}</ref>
Manchin defeated Republican John Raese and Mountain Party candidate [[Bob Henry Baber]] with 60.49% of the total vote and won a full term in the U.S. Senate.<ref name="apps.sos.wv.gov">{{cite web|url=http://apps.sos.wv.gov/elections/results/results.aspx?year=2012&eid=13&county=Statewide|title=Statewide Results : General Election - November 6, 2012|publisher=Apps.sos.wv.gov|accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref>
====2018==== {{main|United States Senate election in West Virginia, 2018}} Manchin is running for re-election in 2018.<ref name=manchinrunning>{{cite web |last=Cheney |first=Kyle |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/04/joe-manchin-wont-run-for-wva-governor-117119.html |title=Joe Manchin won't run for West Virginia governor |date=April 19, 2015 |publisher=''Politico'' |access-date=April 20, 2015}}</ref> He was challenged in the Democratic primary by [[Paula Jean Swearengin]]. Swearengin is an activist and coal miner's daughter who is supported by former members of the [[Bernie Sanders]] campaign. Swearengin criticized Manchin for voting with the Republicans and supporting the policies of [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2017/05/09/justice_democrat_coal_miners_daughter_paula_swearingen_annoucnes_primary_against_west_virginia_sen_joe_manchin.html |title='Justice Democrat' Coal Miner's Daughter Paula Swearingen Announces Primary Challenge Against West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin |work=[[RealClearPolitics]] |last=Hains |first=Tim |date=May 9, 2017|access-date=May 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/joe-manchin-bernie-sanders-primary-challenge-west-virginia-senate-2018/525918/ |title=West Virginia's Conservative Democrat Gets a Primary Challenger |last=Foran |first=Clare |date=May 9, 2017 |publisher=''The Atlantic'' |access-date=August 9, 2017}}</ref>
On the Republican side, Manchin is being challenged by West Virginia Attorney General [[Patrick Morrisey]]. In August 2017, Morrisey publicly asked Manchin to resign from the Senate Democratic leadership team. Manchin responded, "I don't give a shit, you understand?" to a ''Charleston Gazette-Mail'' reporter when asked about Morrisey's call. "I just don't give a shit. Don't care if I get elected, don't care if I get defeated, how about that?"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wvrecord.com/stories/511174813-manchin-says-he-doesn-t-give-a-sh-t-about-morrisey-s-demand|title=Manchin says he 'doesn't give a sh-t' about Morrisey's demand|last=Dickerson|first=Chris|date=August 7, 2017|work=West Virginia Record|access-date=December 1, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Tenure=== Manchin was sworn in by Vice President [[Joe Biden]] on November 15, 2010, succeeding interim Senator [[Carte Goodwin]]. Manchin named Democratic strategist Chris Kofinis to be his chief of staff. Before his swearing-in, rumors suggested that the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] was courting Manchin to change parties.<ref name="Stirewalt Switch">{{cite news| last=Stirewalt|first=Chris|title=Today's Power Play: GOP Sweetens its Offer to Manchin| url= http://politics.blogs.foxnews.com/2010/11/08/todays-power-play-gop-sweetens-its-offer-manchin| accessdate= December 10, 2010|newspaper=FOX News|date=November 8, 2010}}</ref> Although the Republicans later suggested that Manchin was the source of the rumors,<ref name="Drucker">{{cite news| last=Drucker| first= David| title=GOP Suggests Manchin Source of Own Party-Switch Rumors| url= http://www.rollcall.com/news/-200418-1.html| accessdate=December 10, 2010|newspaper=Roll Call| date=November 10, 2010}}</ref> they attempted to convince him again in 2014 after retaking control of the Senate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/223077-mcconnell-expected-to-woo-king-manchin|title=McConnell expected to woo King, Manchin|author=Alexander Bolton|work=The Hill|accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> He again rejected their overtures.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/11/05/joe-manchin-on-election-results-this-is-a-real-a-whooping/|title=Joe Manchin on election results: 'This is a real ass-whuppin'|work=Washington Post|accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> On Election Day 2016, however, Manchin said he might switch parties if necessary to give the GOP a majority in the Senate. He later stated, however, that he would stay in the Democratic Party throughout his time in the Senate.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kleefeld|first1=Eric|title=Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin reportedly hasn't ruled out switching parties in a tied Senate|url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/660613/democratic-sen-joe-manchin-reportedly-hasnt-ruled-switching-parties-tied-senate|website=The Week|accessdate=March 21, 2018}}</ref>
In 2015, Manchin announced that he would seek re-election to the Senate in [[United States Senate elections, 2018|2018]].<ref name=manchinrunning2018>{{cite news|last1=Cheney|first1=Kyle|title=Joe Manchin won't run for West Virginia governor|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/04/joe-manchin-wont-run-for-wva-governor-117119.html?hp=c2_3|accessdate=April 20, 2015|publisher=Politico|date=April 19, 2015}}</ref>
=== Political positions === Joe Manchin is often considered to be a [[Centrism|moderate]] or even [[conservative Democrat]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-immigration-manchin/democratic-senator-criticizes-pelosis-immigration-rhetoric-idUSKBN1FH0RC|title=Democratic senator criticizes Pelosi's immigration comment|date=January 28, 2018|work=Reuters|accessdate=March 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/05/joe-manchin-bernie-sanders-primary-challenge-west-virginia-senate-2018/525918/|title=Will Liberals Force a Conservative Democrat Out of the Senate?|last=Foran|first=Clare|work=The Atlantic|access-date=March 18, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> ''[[FiveThirtyEight|Five ThirtyEight]]'', which tracks Congressional votes, has found that Manchin voted with Trump's position nearly 61% of the time as of June 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/joe-manchin-iii/|title=Tracking Joe Manchin III In The Age Of Trump |last=Bycoffe|first=Aaron|date=January 30, 2017|work=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=March 18, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> ''[[Congressional Quarterly]]'' published a study finding that Manchin voted with Trump's position 71% of the time.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.journalgazette.net/blog/political-notebook/20180214/study-finds-62-of-donnellys-votes-support-trumps-positions |title=Study finds 62% of Donnelly's votes support Trump's positions {{!}} Political notebook {{!}} Journal Gazette |website=www.journalgazette.net|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> According to [[GovTrack]], Joe Manchin is the most conservative Democrat as of 2017 and GovTrack's analysis places Manchin to right of all other Democrats and to the right of Republican Senators [[Susan Collins]] and [[Lisa Murkowski]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/members/joe_manchin/412391|title=Joe Manchin III, Senator for West Virginia - GovTrack.us|website=GovTrack.us|language=en|access-date=2018-07-18}}</ref> The fiscally conservative [[Americans for Prosperity]] gives him a lifetime 32% score and [[John Birch Society|The John Birch Society]], another conservative organization, rated him as agreeing with their position 43% of the time in 2016; conversely, the progressive [[Americans for Democratic Action]] scored Manchin as having a liberal quotient of 35% in 2016 and 60% liberal in 2015.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/7547/joe-manchin-iii#.WzMzw1MvyT8|title=Joe Manchin III's Ratings and Endorsements |website=votesmart.org|accessdate=July 16, 2018}}</ref> ''[[National Journal|The National Journal]]'', in 2013, gave Manchin an overall score of 55% conservative and 46% liberal.<ref name=":1" />
====Coal industry==== On October 6, 2010, Manchin directed a lawsuit aimed at overturning new federal rules concerning [[mountaintop removal mining]]. Filed by the state Department of Environmental Protection, the lawsuit "accuses U.S. EPA of overstepping its authority and asks the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia to throw out the federal agency's new guidelines for issuing [[Clean Water Act]] permits for coal mines." In order to qualify for the permits, mining companies need to prove their projects would not cause the concentration of pollutants in the local water to rise 5 times past the normal level. ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that EPA Administrator [[Lisa P. Jackson|Lisa Jackson]] said the new legislation would protect 95 percent of aquatic life by banning operators from dumping mine waste into [[stream]]s.<ref>{{cite news|title=W.Va. Sues Obama, EPA Over Mining Coal Regulations |url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2010/10/06/06greenwire-wva-sues-obama-epa-over-mining-coal-regulation-48964.html|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=April 26, 2012|author=Patrick Reis|date=October 6, 2010}}</ref>
Manchin has received criticism from environmentalists due to his close family ties to the coal industry. He served as president of Energysystems in the late 1990s before becoming active in politics. On his financial disclosures in 2009 and 2010, his reported earnings from the company were $1,363,916 and $417,255 respectively.<ref name="The New York Times">{{cite news|title=Sen. Manchin Maintains Lucrative Ties to Family-Owned Coal Company|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2011/07/26/26greenwire-sen-manchin-maintains-lucrative-ties-to-family-64717.html?pagewanted=all|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=May 18, 2012|author=MANUEL QUINONES AND ELANA SCHOR|date=July 26, 2011}}</ref> Critics have stated his opposition to health regulations that would raise expenses for the industry are due to his stake in the industry; Jim Sconyers, chairman of West Virginia's [[Sierra Club]] chapter stated that "he's been nothing but a mouthpiece for the coal industry his whole public life."<ref name="The New York Times"/> However, opinions on the subject are mixed; ''[[The Charleston Gazette]]'' noted "the prospect that Manchin's $1.7 million-plus in recent Enersystems earnings might tilt him even more strongly pro-coal might seem remote, given the deep economic and cultural connections that the industry maintains in West Virginia."<ref>{{cite web|title=Sen. Manchin's coal ties under scrutiny |url=http://blogs.wvgazette.com/coaltattoo/2011/07/26/sen-manchins-coal-ties-under-scrutiny/|newspaper=[[The Charleston Gazette]] |accessdate=May 18, 2012|author=Ken Ward Jr.|date=July 26, 2011}}</ref>

Wade]]'' and to instead choose a "centrist."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/394933-manchin-warns-trump-against-picking-court-nominee-who-will-overturn-roe-v |title=Manchin warns Trump against picking court nominee who will overturn Roe v. ====Bipartisanship==== In his first year in office, Manchin met one-on-one with all of his 99 Senate colleagues in an effort to get to know them better.<ref>{{cite web|title=Manchin marks a year in Senate|url=http://www.theintermountain.com/page/content.detail/id/547744.html|publisher=The Inter-Mountain|accessdate=November 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126014848/http://www.theintermountain.com/page/content.detail/id/547744.html|archivedate=January 26, 2013|df=}}</ref>

====Energy==== Manchin sits on the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee and supports a comprehensive, all-of-the-above energy approach that uses coal.<ref>[http://www.loganbanner.com/view/full_story/18105018/article-Manchin--‚ÄòEnergy-belongs-to-all-of-us--regardless-of-party-labels'] {{dead link|date=January 2015}}</ref>

On November 14, 2011, Manchin chaired his first field hearing of that committee in Charleston, West Virginia, to focus on [[Marcellus Formation|Marcellus Shale]] natural gas development and production. Manchin said, "We are literally sitting on top of tremendous potential with the Marcellus shale. We need to work together to chart a path forward in a safe and responsible way that lets us produce energy right here in America."<ref>{{cite web|title=Senator Manchin Leads Field Hearing On Marcellus Shale|url=http://www.wvmetronews.com/news.cfm?func=displayfullstory&storyid=49211|publisher=Wvmetronews.com|date=November 14, 2011}}</ref>

He proposed the LifeBOAT Act, which would fund treatment. He also opposes [[Legalization of marijuana|marijuana legalization]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blau|first1=Max|title=Senator Joe Manchin: Time for a new 'war on drugs' to tackle opioids|url=https://www.statnews.com/2017/03/27/manchin-opioid-war-on-drugs/|website=STAT|accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Joselyn|title=Sen. ==Controversies== ===Heather Bresch=== [[West Virginia University]] (WVU) awarded Manchin's daughter, [[Heather Bresch]], an [[MBA]] in 2007, the year she became [[Chief Operations Officer|COO]] at [[Mylan Inc.]], the third largest generic pharmaceutical manufacturer in the U.S. with headquarters in Morgantown, adjacent to the WVU campus. The ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' reported that in order to justify this degree, university officials had added courses to her transcript that she had never taken and altered grades she had received. The ensuing controversy resulted in the rescinding of her MBA and the resignation of the university president, Mike Garrison, a Manchin family friend, and Garrison's legal counsel and the Dean of the Business School. A panel was convened to fully investigate the measure.<ref name="huntingtonnews.net">{{cite web|title=Joe Manchin III: The Harry Houdini of West Virginia Politics|url=http://www.huntingtonnews.net/8650|publisher=Huntington News|accessdate=April 26, 2012|author=|date=September 1, 2011}}</ref> When the MBA controversy erupted, according to ''[[The Huntington News]]'', Manchin "act[ed] as though he and his wife, Gayle, were somehow the victims of this hoax that almost cost WVU its academic credibility." According to the Huntington News, "the Manchins were seen as people willing to destroy [the university's] reputation rather than admit a mistake."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/opinion/editorials/message-for-wvu-the-board-of-governors-must-restore-credibility-394283 | title=Message for WVU: The board of governors must restore credibility | publisher=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | work=post-gazette.com | date=May 16, 2008 | accessdate=April 26, 2012 | author=Staff}}</ref>
Noting in a December 2011 editorial that the magazine ''[[Esquire]]'' had promoted Heather Bresch as an "American hero" owing to her support for a pharma safety law, the ''Huntington News'' pointed out that the law also protected U.S. pharma firms like Mylan and suggested that the article was a "public makeover" engineered by "the Manchin public relations machine." It also said that Mylan "must have the only corporate Board of Directors in the country that doesn't care about one of their top execs being proven to have a phony MBA degree."<ref>{{cite web|title=EDITORIAL: The Manchin PR Machine Keeps Rollin'. But Who Buys It?|url=http://www.huntingtonnews.net/8650|website=Huntington News|accessdate=March 25, 2018}}</ref>
Despite Manchin's call for a war on drugs, particularly opioids, and his charge that "Big Pharma" had "targeted" his state, Manchin's daughter, as noted, is the CEO of Mylan, a pharmaceutical firm that produces opioids, and Manchin himself accepted "nearly $180,000 in donations from pharmaceutical companies between 2011 and 2016."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Siegel|first1=Zachary|title=West Virginia Senator Joe Manchin: We Need To Declare A War on Drugs|url=https://www.thefix.com/west-virginia-senator-joe-manchin-we-need-declare-war-drugs|website=the fix|accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref> In August 2016, ''[[Fortune Magazine]]'' and the ''[[Washington Post]]'' ran a total of three articles about the fact that the "CEO of the company at the center of the [[EpiPen]] controversy" was Manchin's daughter. The articles noted that skyrocketing EpiPen costs were "the next big flash point in the national debate over skyrocketing prescription drug prices," that Bresch had originally gotten her Mylan job through her father, and that her career had "risen along with her father's, a fact that has not gone unnoticed by her critics." A particular point of controversy was the fact that Bresch had transferred Mylan's official headquarters to the Netherlands, a tax dodge maneuver known as [[tax inversion]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=WIECZNER|first1=Jen|title=The Truth About Mylan CEO's 'Heather Bresch Situation' and Her MBA|url=http://fortune.com/2016/08/26/epipen-mylan-ceo-interview-heather-bresch-mba/|website=Fortune|accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref>
===Family lawsuit=== In a lawsuit filed in July 2014, Dr. John Manchin II, one of Joe Manchin's brothers, sued Joe Manchin and his other brother, Roch Manchin, over a $1.7 million loan. ===Skipping votes and convention=== On December 18, 2010, Manchin skipped the vote to repeal Don't Ask, Don't Tell and the vote on the [[DREAM Act]], regarding immigration. The [[National Republican Senatorial Committee]] criticized Manchin for attending a family Christmas gathering instead of voting on these important issues. "For a Senator who has only been on the job a few weeks," commented the NRSC, "Manchin's absence today, and the apparent lack of seriousness with which he takes the job he was elected to do, speaks volumes."<ref name="Skip votes">{{cite news |title=Joe Manchin Skipped DREAM And DADT Votes For A Christmas Party|date=December 18, 2010 |publisher=[[Talking Points Memo]] |url=http://tpmdc.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/12/joe-manchin-skipped-dream-and-dadt-votes-for-a-christmas-party.php?ref=fpi}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' reported that he was the only Senate Democrat to miss these votes "on two of his party's signature pieces of legislation."<ref>{{cite news|title=Joe Manchin absent for two major Senate votes|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/12/joe-manchin-absent-for-dream-a.html|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 4, 2012|author=Felicia Sonmez|date=December 18, 2010}}</ref> Later, in 2012, Manchin also skipped the Democratic National Convention, saying he planned "to spend this fall focused on the people of West Virginia."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hamby|first1=Peter|last2=Killough|first2=Ashley|title=Manchin to skip Democratic National Convention|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/06/18/manchin-to-skip-democratic-national-convention/|website=political ticker - CNN|accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref>
